Peter, I agree that it would be interesting to experiment with that idea.

=
It does bring up an intriguing issue about role assignment in teams. 
Is it=
 best for each agent to have a fixed role that is assigned a
priori, or sho=
uld roles constantly change based on position?  

For example, in soccer, t=
he roles are assigned based on a kind of
virtual configuration of players t=
hat may never actually exist on the
field after the initial kickoff.  As a =
result, if e.g. a forward drops
back momentarily to play defense, he does n=
ot suddenly switch roles
and *become* a fullback.  Rather, he goes back to =
being a forward.

What would happen if your role in soccer switched instant=
aneously with
your position?  Then the team could end up with problems wher=
e e.g.
everyone on the team becomes offense at the same time by accident
si=
mply because they momentarily moved up the field.  Then who will go
back to=
 defend?  It seems there is a use to roles defined a priori.

Yet I imagine=
 in other domains role makes more sense based on current
position alone.  S=
o it is probably domain-dependent, and an
interesting issue to think about.=


ken


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@.=
..>
wrote:
>
> One thing I thought about when I read the paper was, what wo=
uld 
> happen if the CPPN generates the connectivity patterns depending on =

> the relative positions of each individual in realtime while on the 
> fi=
eld? It would require a great deal of computation time (it has to 
> rebuil=
d the phenotype once per timestep per individual) but it may 
> show intere=
sting results. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanl=
ey" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > David D'Ambrosio and I discuss the potential=
 for HyperNEAT 
> > controlling multiple heterogeneous agents in this new 
=
> > paper, "Generative Encoding for Multiagent Learning," to appear at 
> >=
 GECCO 2008:
> > 
> > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/index.php?
> > option=3Dcom_c=
ontent&task=3Dview&id=3D14&Itemid=3D28#dambrosio.gecco08
> > 
> > Direct Li=
nk:
> > 
> > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/dambrosio_gecco08.pdf
> > 
> > =
We also have a nice sample of videos that depict various evolved 
> > teams=
 in action:
> > 
> > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/multiagenthyperneat
> > 
> > T=
he interesting idea in this paper is that just as a single 
> > connective =
CPPN can encode how a single network varies over space, 
> > it can also en=
code how a *set* of networks (each representing the 
> > policy of one agen=
t on the team) varies over space.  In this way, 
> > HyperNEAT can learn an=
 expression that encodes how policies vary 
> > over the team geometry.  Fo=
r example, in a soccer team agents vary 
> > from defensive to offensive as=
 you move away from the goal.  Part 
> of 
> > the power of this approach i=
s that it means basic skills can be 
> > learned and shared among the whole=
 team, since the CPPN encodes how 
> > those skills vary across the field.
=
> > 
> > ken
> >
>
